feed.title: NewsTracker: cia
feed.subtitle: This is a news tracking demo

entry.title: Lawyer for Pakistani doctor who helped CIA find bin Laden shot dead
entry.summary: "Dr Shakil Afridi had spied on our respected and supreme leader Sheikh Osama to the CIA," TTP-JA spokesman Ehsanullah Ehsan said.

entry.title: Al Qaeda got $1million in CIA money from fund to free Afghan diplomat
entry.summary: The money the CIA delivered while President Hamid Karzai was in charge was used to buy the support of warlords, legislators and others, as well as expenses for clandestine diplomatic trips and housing for senior officials.

entry.title: Afghanistan gave CIA money to al Qaeda for diplomat's ransom: NYT
entry.summary:
Al Qaeda leader Osama bin Laden had at first been concerned about the payment, fearing the CIA knew about the money and had tainted it with poison, radiation or a tracking device, the Times said, and suggested it be converted to another currency.

He was released two years later after Afghanistan paid al Qaeda $5 million, a fifth of which was CIA money that came from an Afghan government fund that received monthly cash deliveries from the agency, the Times said.

In addition to the al Qaeda correspondence, the Times said its story was based on conversations with Afghan and Western officials but that the CIA declined to comment.

entry.title: CIA chief: Social media hampers fight against 'terror'
entry.summary: And while agencies such as the CIA have worked to boost their capability of fighting cyber-based threats, those bent on committing "acts of terror" have used technologies to romanticise their ideology, he added.

entry.title: CIA chief voices concern over social media 'greatly amplifying' terror threat
entry.summary: CIA director John Brennan, in a speech in New York, said such communications only add to the difficulty of dealing with diffuse threats and attacks across the world from groups like Islamic State, known also as ISIL, and others.

entry.title: CIA tried to hack Apple devices for nearly a decade, claim Edward Snowden papers
entry.summary: The CIA did not immediately reply to a request for comment.

entry.title: CIA sought to hack Apple iPhones: Report
Snowden: CIA tried to hack Apple devices for nearly a decade
Carrie no longer CIA officer in next season of 'Homeland'
entry.summary: Gansa later told the PaleyFest audience that CIA officer Carrie Mathison, played by series star Claire Danes, will no longer be an intelligence officer.

entry.title: Danes no longer CIA officer in next 'Homeland'
CIA chief announces sweeping reorganization of US spy agency
entry.summary:
Brennan announced the restructuring to the CIA workforce on Friday, including a new directorate devoted to boosting the CIA's computer hacking skills.

Briefing reporters with Cohen at CIA headquarters this week, Brennan said the changes are necessary to address intelligence gaps that the CIA is not covering.

entry.title: CIA plans major reorganisation and a focus on digital espionage
entry.summary:
CIA Director John Brennan has outlined a plan for the reorganisation of the agency.

The plans were unveiled by CIA director John Brennan to a workforce in which thousands of employees are likely to see changes in which departments they work for, the lines of authority they report to and even where they sit.

The CIA will also create a new directorate focused exclusively on exploiting advances in computer technology and communications.

The Directorate of Digital Innovation will rank alongside the agency's operations and analysis branches, and be responsible for missions ranging from cyber-espionage to the security of the CIA's internal email.

After the reorganisation, Mr Brennan said, the CIA should be in position to "cover the entire universe, regionally and functionally, and so something that's going on in the world falls into one of those buckets".

The head of the CIA's clandestine service recently decided to retire abruptly in part because of opposition to a plan that would strip his position of much of its authority over the agency's covert operations overseas and the teams of spies that it deploys.

entry.title: CIA to make sweeping changes, focus more on cyberops
entry.summary: Brennan told reporters he is creating new units within the CIA, called "mission centers," intended to concentrate the agency's focus on specific challenges or geographic areas, such as weapons proliferation or Africa.

entry.title: CIA to create a digital spy division
entry.summary: "We must place our activities and operations in the digital domain at the very center of all our mission endeavors," Brennan told the CIA workforce on Friday.

entry.title: CIA director announces overhaul of spy agency
entry.summary: Most stations are in U.S. embassies, and various CIA case officers in embassies may be working on different missions for different centers.

entry.title: Ex-CIA chief may avoid prison for leaking military secrets
entry.summary: Petraeus admitted having an affair with Broadwell when he resigned as CIA director in November 2012.

entry.title: Ex-CIA chief may avoid prison for leaking military secrets
entry.summary: Then the CIA director, Petraeus hailed the conviction as a victory for the agency.

entry.title: Ex-CIA chief may avoid prison for leaking military secrets
entry.summary: By comparison, former CIA officer John Kiriakou pleaded guilty in 2012 to one count of intentionally disclosing the identity of a covert agent to a reporter and was sentenced to 30 months in prison.

entry.title: Ex-CIA chief admits sharing military secrets with mistress
entry.summary:
Prosecutors said that after resigning from the CIA, Petraeus signed a form falsely attesting he had no classified material.

Petraeus held the CIA post less than a year, not long enough to leave a significant mark on the spy agency.

entry.title: Ex-CIA chief admits sharing military secrets with mistress
Petraeus OKs guilty plea in data leak to mistress
entry.summary: David Petraeus, the former CIA director and top Army general whose affair with his biographer brought down what many considered a bright political future, has agreed to plead guilty to mishandling classified materials.

entry.title: Former CIA director Petraeus pleads guilty to federal charge
entry.summary:
He served stints as the top U.S. commander in the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan and then as CIA director and was lauded by senior U.S. lawmakers.

Petraeus quit as CIA director under President Barack Obama in November 2012 after the affair was discovered.

entry.title: Former CIA director Petraeus pleads guilty to federal charge: DOJ
entry.summary:
Another former CIA director, John Deutch, was accused of mishandling classified material and agreed to plead guilty, but President Bill Clinton stepped in and pardoned him in 2001.

After resigning from the CIA that November, Petraeus signed a security form assuring that he did not possess any classified information even though the notebooks were still at his home, the documents stated.

The court documents also said Petraeus lied to FBI investigators in October 2012, shortly before he quit the CIA, by saying he had never given classified information to his mistress.

entry.title: Justice Department: Ex-CIA Chief Petraeus to Plead Guilty to Mishandling Classified Materials
Poland to pay $262,000 to inmates held at secret CIA prison
entry.summary: Since 2008, Polish prosecutors have been investigating whether Poland hosted a secret CIA prison, in violation of its laws.

entry.title: Poland to pay $262,000 to inmates held at secret CIA prison
Poland to comply with EU court ruling over CIA secret prison
entry.summary: The court's decision will heap pressure on other European countries to end years of secrecy about their involvement in the CIA's global programme of secret detentions after the September 11, 2001 attacks on the United States.

entry.title: European court confirms Poland's complicity in CIA torture program.
entry.summary:
"This judgment sends a message loud and clear that European states that collaborated in the CIA torture program cannot evade accountability," she said.

After the release of the Senate report, former Polish president Aleksander Kwasniewski and former Prime Minister Leszek Miller acknowledged for the first time that they knew the CIA had been holding people on Polish soil.

entry.title: CIA bought Iraqi chemical weapons say US officials
